Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Improving Transportation Equity to Enhance Food Security for Families Vulnerable to COVID-19
Award.AbstractNarration: This COVID-19 RAPID research program will investigate, and begin to develop mechanisms to address, the lack of access to food (i.e. food insecurity) associated with COVID-19 and the role of transportation challenges leading to food insecurity. The pandemic has exposed some of the underlying inequities in health outcomes in our society. The lack of smartphone and internet access has cut off some families from food delivery services. Consequently, these households are at higher risk of exposure to the virus due to more frequent trips to the grocery store, often by public transit. The research objectives address food insecurity at both the local level and nationwide. The research team will provide research and technical assistance to the City of Detroit’s pilot program to deliver school lunches to vulnerable families. At a national level, the team aims to identify the geographical areas and people most affected by both food and transportation insecurity. The research results will be made available to the public via a nationwide website and database that captures COVID-19 related food insecurity mitigation strategies and best practices.<br/><br/>This project aims to enable data driven discovery and practical insights by linking the available data on food security with information about when, where, how, and why people travel. The team will accomplish this by ingesting the Food Security Index, and related information scraped from tagged content on the Internet, into the teams’ Transportation Equity Open Knowledge Network (OKN) developed under Convergence Accelerator Phase I Pilot project 1936884. The OKN allows stored data, its relationship to other data and to real-world objects and concepts to be understood at a semantic level. This integration will support the development and evaluation of the previously mentioned school lunch delivery program, as well as the identification of people and places most at risk of food insecurity due to a lack of access to transportation. The results are expected to contribute to the response to the current COVID-19 pandemic and any future outbreaks.<br/><br/>This RAPID award is made by the Convergence Accelerator program in the Office of Integrative Activities and is associated with the Convergence Accelerator Track A: Open Knowledge Network.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Covid-19 pandemic exacerbated underlying inequities in our society. Excluding health outcomes, nowhere is this disparity more pronounced and consequential than access to food. The closure of food service outlets and movement to an ?order delivery? business mode during the shut-down period in many states, coupled with reduced public transit services, severely affected transit dependent households. This was the motivation for the Covid Food Delivery Program (CFDP), a meal delivery service for individuals from Covid positive and/or food insecure public transit dependent households during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Using the City of Detroit as a testbed, the project addresses key needs of vulnerable and low-income communities struggling with food insecurity.  Key elements of the project included identifying and estimating the magnitude of Detroit?s food insecure population at the household level. Activities also included designing and implementing an intervention to address the inability to access food as well as evaluating the effectiveness of the intervention. The programmatic activities were coordinated by a team of personnel from Detroit?s Department of Parks and Recreation.

Low-income, marginalized, and vulnerable households contend with the residual effects of structural racism such as redlining, which has impacted not only transit accessibility but also the proliferation of food deserts. Targeted households were those receiving SNAP/EBT benefits, that did not have a vehicle and had no internet access. Data was used from multiple sources to generate estimates of these households including their composition and key demographic characteristics of these households. In addition, we used secondary data obtained from the Detroit Metro Area Communities Study (DMACS) survey to capture the severity and impact of the pandemic on this segment of the population, with an emphasis on the shut-down period. With a focus on households that met the criteria specified above, we estimate that across Michigan, 71,600 households fall within this segment of the population of which 27,200 households are in Wayne County and approximately 20,800 households in Detroit.

Our research demonstrated how these estimates, using a multitude of datasets, could be calculated at fine geographic areas across the U.S., thus ensuring the ease of replicating our approach for different geographic areas and affording interventions at neighborhood, census tract or block group level. Beyond these estimates, a core element of our research involved documenting process issues, and the coordination required among the multitude of partners involved in CFDP. These issues included addressing the patchwork of funding which kept on changing throughout the program; constraints on the ideal mix of food type ? shelf stable and fresh produce boxes; routing challenges; issues with referral pipelines; managing uncertainties with volunteer staffing; and finally, the requirements imposed on deliveries based on household composition and Covid status.

Output and outcome measures from the program revealed that more than 900 households benefitted from the food delivery program with these households receiving on average, 6.6 weeks of food delivery services. We acknowledge that this is only a fraction of the estimated food insecure households without adequate transportation. Data from the CFDP data dashboard (N=350) obtained through a random sample of patrons using a number generator revealed that 86% of recipients reported having enough or more than enough food each week during the duration of their use of the food delivery program services, though only 70% of the food consumption, on average per week, came from CFDP; 69% mentioned the need to supplement food received from CFDP with other food source(s) while 35% were first time beneficiaries of CFDP ? an indication of novel cases of food insecurity. In addition, analyses of the open-ended responses revealed that there were limitations to the food deliveries, with a lack of dairy, meat, and other refrigerated items being the largest source of these issues. Beyond this, a key element of our research effort included presenting the ?Sustainability Recommendations for the COVID Food Delivery Program (CFDP)? to CFDP during the first quarter of 2021. The plan has been instrumental in guiding the program?s redesign and in securing additional resources to the tune of $1.5 million which will double existing capacity and sustain the program?s implementation until 2024.

These results and findings provide rich insights that allow other cities and municipalities to learn from the City of Detroit?s experience in designing, implementing, and modifying the program to respond to the needs created by the COVID-19 crisis. We believe that other cities will benefit from our documentation, learn from our experience and be able to modify similar program designs to address local peculiarities.
